text: In 1845, a deadly disease struck the farms of Ireland, killing all the lumber potato plants.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: The death of a single crop species might not seem so important. But in Ireland in 1845, people depended almost solely on the potato for food.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: The death of one species caused a terrible famine. Now some scientists are worried that such a famine could happen again, but on a much wider scale.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: Over the centuries, farmers have discovered thousands of different species of food crops. Each species has special qualities.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: Some can be grown in very hot or cold climates. Others are not affected by certain diseases. However, you won't find many of these species in your local supermarket.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: To feed the 7 billion people on earth, most farmers today are growing only species of plants that are easy to produce in large numbers. Meanwhile, thousands of other species are becoming extinct.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: For example, in the Philippines, there were once thousands of varieties of rice. Now fewer than 100 are grown there.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: In China, 90% of the wheat varieties grown just a century ago have disappeared. Experts believe that over the past century, we have allowed more than half of the world's food varieties to disappear.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: In the 1920s and 1930s, he collected around 400,000 seeds from five continents. More recently, others have continued the work he began.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: There are now around 1,700 seed banks in countries around the world.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, which preserves almost one million seed samples, has one of the largest collections.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: In the U.S. state of Iowa, Diane Ott Wheely and her husband founded Heritage Farm, a place where people can store and trade seeds.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: Initially, Ott Wheely wanted to preserve historic plant varieties, like the seeds her great-grandfather brought to the United States more than 100 years ago from Germany.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: But the people at Heritage Farm don't just store the seeds. They plant them.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009

text: By doing this, they are reintroducing foods into the marketplace that haven't been grown for years. These food species are not just special in terms of appearance or flavor, they also offer farmers food solutions for the future from the past.
speaker: EN_B00003_S00009
